intro: Acaena trifida var. argentella, commonly known as silver bramble, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a member of the rose family (Rosaceae) and is characterized by its spiny stems and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces spherical, woody fruits that contain seeds covered in hooked bristles. It thrives in coastal and subalpine environments, often growing in rocky or sandy soils. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and natural reserves.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena trifida var. argentella is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the central and southern regions. This variety thrives in a variety of habitats, including rocky soils and open vegetation. It is commonly observed in areas with a temperate climate and is often associated with native shrubs. The plant plays a role in the ecological systems of its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena trifida var. argentella was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive silver foliage. The introduction occurred in the 19th century during the early days of European settlement. It has since spread beyond cultivated areas and is now considered a potential weed in some regions. Its distribution is primarily confined to the North Island, though it has been reported in parts of the South Island as well.
